content: The Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (HKSAR) held elections for its Legislative Council (Legco) on September 9, 2012, with the newly elected members having the opportunity to consider political reforms for universal suffrage in 2017 and 2020. The selection of CY Leung as Chief Executive may impact Hong Kong's democracy prospects. The 2012 election results in Hong Kong may lead to a political stalemate for democratic reforms, with pro-democracy members winning enough seats to block unacceptable election reforms. The selection of CY Leung as Chief Executive, engineered by the Chinese government, could impact Hong Kong's democracy prospects. The outcome of Hong Kong's 2012 elections is crucial to Congress due to the Hong Kong Policy Act of 1992 and the Basic Law's provisions for universal suffrage. The 2012 elections in Hong Kong are important for Congress due to the Basic Law's provisions for universal suffrage. Some scholars believe Hong Kong could be a testing ground for democratic reforms in Mainland China, signaling China's willingness to consider political changes. The Chinese Communist Party's stance on political reforms in Hong Kong may indicate its opposition to changes in its own political system. Congress may consider supporting democracy in Hong Kong through funding and educational events to raise awareness. The Basic Law established an executive-led government in Hong Kong. The Chief Executive of Hong Kong is selected by an Election Committee, which was expanded in 2010. Most members are appointed by organizations, with some Legco and District Council members included. The date for selecting the fourth Chief Executive is pending. The selection of Hong Kong's fourth Chief Executive was set for March 25, 2012. Three candidates submitted nomination papers: Henry Tang Ying-yen, CY Leung, and Albert Ho Chun-yan. Tang was the frontrunner with support from 390 Election Committee members, while Leung was the dark horse candidate with 305 supporters. Albert Ho Chun-yan, the pan-democrat candidate, received backing from 188 Election Committee members for his nomination. Henry Tang's bid for Chief Executive faced challenges early on due to an affair scandal and questions about his academic credentials. On February 13, 2012, Hong Kong media reported illegal construction work on one of Henry Tang's houses, including an unauthorized basement with a private movie theater and wine cellar. Tang admitted to the illegal basement but blamed his wife for its construction, leading to a loss of public support and a shift towards his opponent Leung. After a debate, a survey showed support for Leung over Tang and Ho. Rumors spread about Chinese government support shifting to Leung. The official vote took place on March 25, 2012, with Leung winning in the first round with 689 votes, while Tang finished second with 285 votes. Leung won the election with 689 votes, becoming Hong Kong's fourth Chief Executive. His swearing-in ceremony sparked controversy as he used Mandarin Chinese instead of Cantonese, signaling a closer alignment with the Chinese government. The Legislative Council (Legco) in Hong Kong has limited power under the Basic Law. Members can introduce legislation not related to public expenditure or government structure. Legco can block legislation and has limited oversight of the government. It consists of members elected by geographical and functional constituencies. In the 2012 Legco election, Hong Kong's 3.5 million eligible voters could cast two votes - one in geographical constituencies and another in functional constituencies. Less than 1 in 10 residents could vote in functional constituencies before this election. The 2012 Legco election saw a turnout rate of 52.3% with 1.83 million eligible voters casting their ballots. The increase in voter turnout was attributed to public discontent with the Hong Kong government, particularly regarding the national education curriculum. Chief Executive CY Leung's decision to make the curriculum optional just before the election did not alleviate concerns about recent government policies. Popular concern about recent changes in Hong Kong government policies remains high leading up to the Legco election. In December 2010, election reforms increased the number of Legco seats from 60 to 70, with half elected by geographical constituencies and half by functional constituencies. The seats were divided proportionately among districts, with traditional and new functional constituencies included. The election reforms in Hong Kong introduced new District Council (second) functional constituency seats, allowing 3.2 million voters to participate. These seats were known as "super seats" and the elected members as "super members." Political parties in Hong Kong are divided into pan-democrats and pro-establishment camps. The political parties in Hong Kong are divided into pan-democrats, who support a rapid transition to democracy and more independence for Hong Kong, and the pro-Beijing camp, who prefer a gradual transition and closer ties with China. The pan-democrats include the ADPL, CP, DP, LP, LSD, and PP, while the pro-Beijing camp includes the DAB, ES, FTU, LiP, NPP, and other parties. In Hong Kong, political parties are divided into pan-democrats, who support rapid democracy transition, and the pro-Beijing camp, who prefer a gradual transition. The geographical constituency seats in Legco are highly contested, with multiple slates of candidates running to increase their chances of winning seats. For example, in New Territories West, the pro-Beijing DAB ran three slates and the pan-democrat Democratic Party ran two slates. The Democratic Party and DAB ran multiple slates in the election. DAB won 10 out of 35 geographical constituency seats, while Civic Party won all five of their slates. People Power and Labour Party also had strong showings, with People Power winning three seats. Power easily won three seats in Kowloon East and nearly a fourth. The Labour Party's three slates all secured seats. The League of Social Democrats only won one out of four seats they contested, but their winning candidate in New Territories East, Leung Kwok Hung (known as "Cheung Mo" or "Long Hair"), received the most votes in that district. The "super seats" were closely watched in the September 9, 2012, Legco vote, with over 3 million eligible voters. The nomination process for these seats was complex. The nomination process for the five "super seats" in the Legco vote favored pro-Beijing parties, excluding most pan-democrat parties. Popular opposition to "national education" and discontent with "mainlandization" favored pan-democrat candidates. Only elected members of Hong Kong's 18 District Councils could be candidates for these seats. On November 6, 2011, Hong Kong held elections for 412 District Council members. Four parties, including pan-democrat and pro-Beijing parties, won seats. The nomination process required support from at least 15 District Council members for each candidate or slate of candidates. The Labour Party and LSD were excluded from the race. Seven candidates or slates ran for the five "super seats" in the Hong Kong elections, with pan-democrat and pro-Beijing parties participating. The DAB, Democratic Party, ADPL, HKFTU, and an independent candidate were among those running. Pan-democrat slates won three seats, while the DAB and HKFTU secured the other two seats. The functional constituencies in Hong Kong, a legacy of British rule, consist of economic and social groups important to the region. Initially created to ensure support for the British Governor, they now serve to back the Chief Executive. These constituencies have a limited number of eligible voters and play a significant role in Hong Kong's political landscape. Functional constituencies in Hong Kong have a limited number of eligible voters, which can be individuals, companies, or organizations. The number of eligible voters varies across constituencies, with the Finance seat having the lowest at 132 and the Education seat having the highest at nearly 90,000. In the recent election, 16 out of 30 traditional functional constituency seats had only one candidate who was declared the winner without a vote, while nine seats had two candidates. The Financial Services seat had the most candidates with a total of five. Pro-Beijing parties and independents won 24 out of the 30 traditional functional constituency seats. In the recent election, Pro-Beijing parties and independents won 24 out of 30 traditional functional constituency seats. Economic Synergy, FLU, and New Century Forum also secured seats. Pan-democrats won six seats, including the Civic Party, Labour Party, and independent candidates. The pro-Beijing coalition, led by the DAB with 13 seats, will hold 43 seats in the newly elected Legco. The pan-democrat coalition will have 27 members, with challenges in keeping their loose coalitions together. Newer parties within the pro-Beijing coalition have differing views on issues affecting Hong Kong's middle and working class population. Issues regarding workers' rights in Hong Kong may cause disagreement within the pro-Beijing coalition and the pan-democrats, particularly between the Civic Party and Democratic Party, and the LSD and People Power parties. The disagreement stems from the decision to accept the election reform compromise in 2010, as outlined in Articles 45 and 68 of the Basic Law. The goal is for universal suffrage in electing the Chief Executive and Legislative Council members. The Basic Law outlines the method for selecting the Chief Executive and Legislative Council members through universal suffrage. Election reforms in 2010 followed procedures set by annexes and a decision by China's NPCSC in 2007, setting 2017 for Chief Executive and 2020 for Legislative Council direct elections. The Basic Law outlines the method for selecting the Chief Executive and Legislative Council members through universal suffrage. The new Chief Executive and Legco will have the opportunity to fulfill the ultimate aim stated in the Basic Law and approve legislation to elect the next Chief Executive and the 2020 Legco by universal suffrage. Amendments to the Basic Law stipulate different conditions for altering the selection process for the Chief Executive and Legco. Amendments to the Basic Law require a two-thirds majority of Legislative Council members and the Chief Executive's consent, with approval from the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress. The process for amending the election process in Hong Kong involves six steps, including reporting to the NPCSC, determining the need for amendment, introducing a bill of amendments to Legco, passing the bill by a two-thirds majority, and approval by the Chief Executive. The 2012 Legco election results are relevant as the pan-democrats can block any proposal to amend the election process if they remain unified. The pan-democrats may struggle to attract support from the pro-Beijing coalition for election reforms, risking the chance for universal suffrage in the 2017 and 2020 elections. Key issues include the nomination process for Chief Executive candidates and the future of functional constituencies. The current process for nominating Chief Executive candidates in Hong Kong requires the support of at least 150 Election Committee members. This limits the number of potential candidates to eight people. The nomination process is expected to be carried out by a nominating committee following democratic procedures. The selection of committee members will be a key issue in the government's proposal for universal suffrage. The key issues in the process for selecting Chief Executive candidates in Hong Kong include concerns about the independence and representativeness of the nomination committee, as well as the debate over the nomination threshold. The existence of functional constituencies is also a controversial aspect of Hong Kong's governance structure. The functional constituencies in Hong Kong are a controversial aspect of the governance structure. Some view them as non-democratic and advocate for their elimination to fulfill the "ultimate aim" of democracy. Others believe they can align with this aim if every eligible voter can vote for a functional constituency member. The issue of company and organizational votes within these constituencies is also contentious, with some arguing that only individuals should have voting rights. The status of functional constituencies in Hong Kong is crucial for election reforms, as at least 12 members must support the changes. Some doubt if these members will vote to eliminate their own seats. The potential for future election reforms in Hong Kong will test China's commitment to democratization in the region. The Chinese government plays a direct role in approving Hong Kong's election reforms, potentially using it as a model for democratic reforms in mainland China and to showcase the "one country, two systems" policy to Taiwan. The Chinese government's involvement in approving Hong Kong's election reforms is a key indicator of its stance on democratization. The NPCSC's decision in 2007 interprets Article 45 of the Basic Law, requiring approval of reforms by two-thirds of Legco members and the Chief Executive. This process reflects China's attitude towards Hong Kong's democracy and may influence discussions on election reforms. The NPCSC may intervene in election reform discussions in Hong Kong, as seen in 2007 when it ended debates on universal suffrage for the Chief Executive election. Pan-democrats supported universal suffrage and eliminating functional constituencies, while pro-Beijing parties opposed these reforms. The NPCSC's decision effectively halted the discussion by favoring the retention of functional constituencies. The NPCSC's decision in 2007 ended debates on universal suffrage for the Chief Executive and Legco elections in Hong Kong, setting timelines for their implementation. The concept of "one country, two systems" was originally meant for China and Taiwan's reunification but has been applied in Hong Kong. China's promise to grant Hong Kong a high degree of autonomy and maintain its "capitalist system and way of life" for 50 years is outlined in the Basic Law. Some scholars believe China uses Hong Kong as a model for Taiwan reunification, potentially accepting Hong Kong's democratization as part of the process. Others doubt China will take such risks. Some analysts believe China may use Hong Kong to test democratic reforms that could influence mainland China. The Chinese government might control the nomination process for Chief Executive candidates while allowing universal suffrage for the election. The nomination process for Chief Executive candidates in Hong Kong may be controlled by the CCP, while universal suffrage for the election gives the appearance of democracy. The preservation of functional constituencies and control over eligibility criteria may allow the CCP to indirectly prevent undesirable legislation. The US supports democracy in Hong Kong through funding for civil society and democratic practices. The United States has expressed disappointment in Chinese government intervention in Hong Kong's governance and hopes for future election reforms. Some NGOs in Hong Kong are cautious about accepting U.S. funding for civil society development to avoid drawing unwanted attention from Chinese and Hong Kong governments. The United States hopes for election reforms in Hong Kong to signal China's attitude towards human rights and civil liberties. Facilitation of democratic reforms may indicate China's new leadership is open to democratic governance, while thwarting popular election reforms could show resistance to democratization.
